Graphical abstract In this study, a series of copper species supported on TiO2 catalysts were synthesized. With respect to the CuO/TiO2 catalyst, around 75% NO x was reduced between 200 and 250 °C and a negative deNO x efficiency was achieved above 350 °C. The existence of plentiful reactive surface oxygen species favored the activation of NO x and NH3, thus leading to satisfactory activity levels at lower temperatures. Due to this, NH3 over-oxidized to NO x was also facilitated and the portion of NH3 reducing NO x to N2 or N2O in the reactions showed a downward trend as temperature increased, which explained the decreasing high-temperature NO x removal efficiency of this sample. For CuSO4/TiO2 and SO2-treated CuO/TiO2 catalysts, the generation of plentiful strong acid sites at the expense of the reactive surface oxygen species suppressed the activation of NH3 and NO x to some extent at lower temperatures and also negatively affected the over-oxidation of NH3 to NO x at elevated temperatures, which explained the changes in the operating temperature window to a high temperature region. Keywords SCR sulfate activity CuO/TiO2 CuSO4/TiO2 1 Introduction The selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x by NH3 is well accepted as a superior technology for the degradation of NO x from both diesel engines and power stations [1]. Generally, equation (1) is regarded as the main reaction in the SCR cycles [2]. (1) 4 N H 3 + 4 N O + O 2 → 4 N 2 + 6 H 2 O Given that the reaction temperature increases, especially above 350 °C, apart from this main reaction, several side reactions involving NH3 oxidized to NO x may occur (equations (2) and (3)). This always leads to a deficit in the ammonia levels to reduce NO x and consequently elevates the NO x concentration of flue gas. This is considered as the main barrier in maintaining an excellent NO x removal efficiency at higher temperatures [3]. (2) 4 N H 3 + 5 O 2 → 4 N O + 6 H 2 O (3) 4 N H 3 + 7 O 2 → 4 N O 2 + 6 H 2 O While at lower temperatures, the occurrence of the aforementioned side reactions can be suppressed to a certain extent, ensuring that sufficient ammonia species can function as the reductant to participate in the degradation of NO x . Even so, insufficient activation of NH3 and NO x because of the fairly low reaction temperature still leaves the NO x removal efficiency below a satisfactory value [4]. Thus, finding a way to maintain a sufficient deNO x efficiency in a wide temperature range is still an important research topic. It is acknowledged that the activity of the catalysts, the key component in this technology, mainly decides the deNO x efficiency of the whole SCR system. Hence, a significant amount of effort has been put into developing highly active catalysts. Ce-, Fe-, and Mn-based catalysts are proven to be capable of exhibiting excellent activity and N2 selectivity in a certain temperature region [5–10]. However, some of the important factors in the performance of the catalysts still must be explored. On the basis of the SCR mechanisms, it is considered that acid and redox sites are the main active sites of the catalysts [1]. This research result indicates that tuning the catalyst acidity and oxidability might suppress the over-oxidation of NH3 to NO x at elevated temperatures and enhance the activation of NH3 and NO x in the lower temperature region simultaneously, thereby realizing the assumption of broadening the operating temperature window of the SCR systems. As is reported in the literature, sulfate anions and CuO are known for their novel acidity and oxidative ability, which could be adopted as the acid sites for NH3 adsorption and redox sites for NO x and NH3 activation, respectively [11,12]. This means that the impact of oxidative ability and acidity on the catalyst’s low- and high-temperature performance could be studied through combining CuO and sulfate anions as a model, which would build a solid foundation for developing new catalysts that may exhibit good performance over a broad temperature range. For these reasons, we took CuO/TiO2, CuSO4/TiO2, and SO2-treated CuO/TiO2 (designated as CuO/TiO2+SO2) catalysts as the research subjects in this study. X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman, N2 adsorption, hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and in situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS) characterizations were chosen to explore the structural and chemical properties of these three samples. Through this analysis, we found crucial factors in the performance of the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of the series samples CuO/TiO2 and CuSO4/TiO2 catalysts were prepared through the conventional wetness impregnation method. Typically, 4 g TiO2 powder (Degussa P25) was mixed with a Cu(NO3)3 or CuSO4 solution and then the mixture was stirred at 60 °C until the excess water evaporated. Afterwards, samples were dried for an additional 8 h at 95 °C and finally calcined at 500 °C for 5 h. The CuO/TiO2+SO2 sample was obtained by treating the as-synthesized CuO/TiO2 catalyst in the SO2- and O2-containing feed gas (SO2: 500 ppm; O2: 5%) at 300 °C for 16 h. The molar ratio of Cu/Ti was fixed to 0.05 for all samples. V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst containing 0.8 wt.% V2O5 and 5 wt.% WO3 was prepared using the conventional wetness impregnation method. Certain amounts of NH4VO3 and H40N10O41W12·xH2O were dissolved in an oxalic acid solution followed by the impregnation of 4 g TiO2 powder (P25). The mixture was stirred at 60 °C until the excess water evaporated. Finally, sample was dried for an additional 8 h at 95 °C and calcined at 500 °C for 5 h. 2.2 Performance tests of the series samples Performance tests were conducted in a micro reactor using a 0.3 g sample. A simulated flue gas of 500 ml min-1, which contained NH3 of 500 ppm (if necessary), NO of 500 ppm (if necessary), O2 of 5%, and balance N2, was purged into the system. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was calculated to be 100000 mL g-1 h-1. NO, NO2, NH3, and N2O signals were continuously analyzed with a Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer. Equations (4)–(8) were adopted to calculate the NO x conversion (X), NH3 conversion (N), N2 selectivity (S), NO oxidation efficiency (O), and NO oxidation reaction rate (k) of the series catalysts [13]. (4) X = 100 % × ( N O i n - N O o u t - N O 2 o u t ) / N O i n (5) N = 100 % × ( N H 3 i n - N H 3 o u t ) / N H 3 i n (6) S = 100 % × [ 1 - 2 × N 2 O o u t / ( N O i n + N H 3 i n ) ] (7) O = 100 % × ( N O i n - N O o u t ) / N O i n (8) k = O × [ N O ] i n × F 22.4 × W In these equations, [NO]in and [NH3]in are denoted as the inlet concentrations of NO and NH3; [NO]out, [NO2]out, [N2O]out, and [NH3]out represent the outlet concentrations of NO, NO2, N2O, and NH3; F and W represent the gas flow rate and catalyst weight, respectively. 2.3 Characterizations of the series samples XRD experiments were performed on a Rigaku D/max 2550PC diffractometer, in which CuK α was used as the radiative source. Raman measurements were carried out on a Renishaw inVia spectrometer at room temperature. N2 adsorption and desorption experiments were conducted on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 apparatus. XPS profiles were obtained on a Thermal ESCALAB 250 electron spectrometer. The C 1s line (284.5 eV) was used to calibrate the binding energies of the bands of the samples investigated. NH3-TPD profiles were obtained on a Micromeritics ChemiSorb 2720 using a 0.1 g sample. After the pretreatment process, the tested sample was fed with NH3 for 60 min at 60 °C and then flushed by Ar for 30 min. Finally, the temperature was ramped to 600 °C for 54 min, during which a mass spectrometer was adopted to continuously collect the NH3 signal. H2-TPR characterization was carried out on a Micromeritics ChemiSorb 2720 using a 50 mg sample. After the pretreatment process, the temperature was decreased to 50 °C and finally increased to 700 °C in H2 for 65 min. In this process, a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to continuously monitor the consumption of H2. NH3 adsorption and desorption in situ DRIFTS characterizations were conducted on a Thermal Nicolet 6700 FTIR system using a ca. 0.2 g sample. First, the tested sample was pretreated at 350 °C under N2 for 60 min to remove the adsorbed impurities. The background spectra were collected at 350 °C, 300 °C, 250 °C, 200 °C, 150 °C, and 100 °C. After that, 1000 ppm of NH3 was purged into the cell and the sample was saturated with NH3 at 100 °C for 60 min. Then the sample was flushed by N2 for 30 min to remove the physically adsorbed NH3. Finally, the sample was heated to the desired temperature points to monitor the variations of the surface nature. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Performance of the series samples 3.1.1 DeNOx performance Fig. 1 demonstrates the performances of these three Cu-based samples. With respect to the CuO/TiO2 catalyst, around 75% NO x was reduced between 175 and 250 °C. Given that the reaction temperature increases, catalyst activity begins to present a decreasing tendency. It is worth noting that the deNO x efficiency becomes negative when the reaction temperature exceeds 350 °C. That could be ascribed to the over-oxidation of the reductant NH3 with extra NO x formed as a consequence [14]. By contrast, the operating temperature presents an upward trend for the two sulfate-containing samples; more than 80% NO x is reduced within the temperature window of 250 to 375 °C for the CuSO4/TiO2 catalyst and nearly 100% deNO x efficiency can be observed between 325 and 350 °C for the SO2-treated CuO/TiO2 sample. When compared with the commercially used V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, we can see that among these three Cu-based samples, CuSO4/TiO2 exhibits a higher NO x removal efficiency than the commercially available V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst in low- and moderate-temperature regions (Fig. S1). At 350 °C, the typical operating temperature point of power plants, NO x conversion of CuSO4/TiO2 can even reach ca. 100%, which is comparable to that of the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst. This result suggests that CuSO4/TiO2 might be a potential catalyst in practical applications. Fig. 1(b) demonstrates the NH3 conversion results of these three samples. With respect to the CuO/TiO2 catalyst, the NH3 conversion value is almost equal to that of the NO x conversion below 200 °C, suggesting that NH3 mainly serves as the reductant in the SCR reactions in this temperature region. Given an ongoing increasing temperature process, the NH3 conversion value starts to be higher than the NO x conversion value and even reaches 100% above 250 °C; this result indicates that several unwanted reactions involving NH3 over-oxidized to NO x have taken place. N2 selectivity over these three samples is presented in Fig. 1(c). We can see that the N2 selectivity of CuO/TiO2 continuously decreases to ca. 84% as the temperature increases to 300 °C; further increasing the reaction temperature, catalyst N2 selectivity rebounds. While for the sulfate-containing samples, the N2 selectivity value remains higher than 92% within the temperature region investigated, which is suggestive of negative effects of sulfate species on producing the unwanted N2O product. From these results, a conclusion can be drawn that sulfate anions might have a decisive role to play in the deNO x activity and N2 selectivity of the catalysts. Considering the SCR mechanisms, it seems that sulfate species might make a real difference in the acidity and oxidability of the catalysts, which would be uncovered by adopting some characterizations in the following sections. 3.1.2 NH3 catalytic oxidation To explain the decreasing NO x removal efficiency of the catalysts at elevated temperature points, we carried out the NH3 oxidation experiments and the corresponding data are presented in Fig. 2 . Given that the temperature rises, NH3 conversion of the CuO/TiO2 catalyst exhibits an upward trend and reaches ca. 100% above 250 °C. Conversely, these two sulfate-containing samples are observed with a relatively low NH3 oxidation activity: only ca. 12% and ca. 8% NH3 is oxidized at 300 °C for CuSO4/TiO2 and SO2-treated CuO/TiO2 samples, respectively. Considering the yield of NO, NO2, and N2O, a conclusion can be drawn that the main products of the CuO/TiO2 catalyst during the NH3 oxidation process could be ascribed to NO and NO2 with the temperature exceeding 350 °C, as evidenced by the far higher outlet concentrations of NO and NO2 than that of N2O. To a certain extent, this result confirms that the decreased high-temperature deNO x efficiency of the CuO/TiO2 catalyst could be explained by the over-oxidation of NH3 to NO and NO2. Besides, the N2O profile of the Cu/TiO2 sample exhibits a volcano shape, which could also explain the increased N2 selectivity above 300 °C to a certain extent. Instead, an obvious decrease in the formation amount of NO, NO2, and N2O takes place for the sulfate containing samples; this constitutes an important explanation for the elevated NO x removal efficiency and N2 selectivity of CuSO4/TiO2 and SO2-treated CuO/TiO2 catalysts at higher temperatures. Moreover, these two sulfate-containing samples exhibit a similar production amount of NO, NO2, and N2O, thereby having similar high-temperature activity and selectivity. 3.1.3 NO catalytic oxidation The NO oxidation results, which could explain the higher activity of CuO/TiO2 than that of the other two sulfate-containing samples at lower temperatures, are illustrated in Fig. 3 . Given increasing temperatures, the reaction rates of the series samples exhibit an upward trend. Compared with the sulfate-containing samples, a relatively high NO oxidation reaction rate could be observed for the CuO/TiO2 catalyst, which can facilitate the so-called “fast SCR” pathway and, therefore, leads to satisfactory low-temperature activity [1]. 3.2 Physicochemical properties 3.2.1 Textural structures Crystalline phases of these three catalysts were explored using an XRD method and the corresponding patterns are presented in Fig. 4 . All three samples present typical anatase and rutile TiO2 phases. The disappearance of the diffraction peaks ascribed to CuO or CuSO4 crystallites indicates a good dispersion of copper species on TiO2 supports, as expected. Fig. 5 reveals the Raman spectra of the series catalysts. Five Raman characteristic peaks could be clearly observed at 144, 197, 395, 516, 638 cm-1, suggesting that samples are mainly composed of the anatase phase [15]. The absence of the main rutile peak centered at 445 cm-1 could be explained by the low sensitivity of the rutile Eg Raman mode [16]. N2 adsorption data of these three Cu-based samples are presented in Table 1 . We can see that the CuSO4/TiO2 catalyst possesses the largest surface area (50 m2 g-1), followed by the CuO/TiO2 (42 m2 g-1) and CuO/TiO2+SO2 (40 m2 g-1) samples. To eliminate the possibility that surface area directly decides the catalyst activity, we calculated the surface area normalized reaction rates of these three samples. As is shown in Fig. S2, it can be concluded that chemical properties, opposed to textural structures, decide the performance of the catalysts. In the following sections, several characterizations were adopted to investigate the acidity and oxidability of these three samples so that the key points in the reactions could be clearly recognized. 3.2.2 Acidity NH3 was used as a probe to determine the surface acidity of the three samples, and the data are presented in Fig. 6 . It can be seen that no obvious NH3 desorption peaks come out in the heating process for the CuO/TiO2 sample. Considering the potential appearance of a baseline shift during the experiment period, it can be assumed that there are few acid sites on CuO/TiO2 and the area of its NH3 desorption peaks is close to zero. Instead, three obvious NH3 desorption peaks come out during heating for the sulfate-containing samples, which is suggestive of an enhancement in the catalyst acidity. As reported in literature, the first peak ranging between 100 and 170 °C is ascribed to weakly adsorbed NH3; the second peak at 170-250 °C is related to the adsorbed NH3 owning an intermediate stability and the third peak, whose temperature exceeds 250 °C, is indexed to strongly adsorbed NH3 [17]. After calculating the area of the NH3 desorption peaks of these three samples, it can be seen that the amount of ammonia species adsorbed on the CuO/TiO2+SO2 sample almost triples compared to that of CuSO4/TiO2 catalyst. Thus, it can be concluded that the acidity of these three samples follows the order of CuO/TiO2+SO2 > CuSO4/TiO2 > CuO/TiO2. To obtain detailed information on the acidity of these three catalysts, NH3 adsorption in situ DRIFTS characterization was carried out and the resulting IR data are presented in Fig. 7 . After NH3 adsorption, four peaks arise indexed to stretching vibrations of N-H bonds at 3180, 3264, 3336, and 3392 cm-1 for all three samples [18]; the CuO/TiO2 surface is only covered by coordinated NH3 (1200-1260 cm-1 and 1600-1620 cm-1), whereas CuSO4/TiO2 and SO2-treated CuO/TiO2 surfaces are mainly covered by ionic NH4 + (1438, 1689 cm-1) [19]. Besides, the presence of two negative peaks at 1355 (O = S=O) and 3649 cm-1 (-OH) for the sulfate-containing samples could be ascribed to the coverage of sulfate anions and hydroxyl groups by ammonia species [20]. Based on the calculated ratio [(Bronsted acid sites)/(Lewis acid sites)] (B/L for short) in Fig. 7(b), one conclusion can be drawn that variations have occurred in the catalyst’s acid properties by sulfate species; and sulfate species, as the main Bronsted acid sites, replace Lewis acid sites to become the dominant acid sites to adsorb NH3 for the sulfate-containing catalysts. To clarify the stability of the bonded ammonia species over these three Cu-based catalysts, NH3 desorption in situ DRIFTS characterization was carried out and the resulting IR data can be seen in Fig. 8 . Given that the temperature increases, the peak intensity for NH3 linked to Lewis acid sites belonging to CuO/TiO2 sample continues to decrease and almost vanishes at 300 °C. By contrast, characteristic bands related to the adsorbed ammonia species could still be clearly detected for the sulfate-containing samples even at 350 °C. This is indicative of an elevated stability of ammonia species over the sulfate-containing catalysts than those on the CuO/TiO2 sample surface, which, to a certain extent, supports the conclusions from the NH3-TPD results in Fig. 6. To summarize, sulfate species, considered as the sites with strong acidity, primarily contribute to adsorbing NH3 on the catalysts, which can sometimes impact the activation of NO x and NH3 to a certain degree, thus making the operating temperature window shift towards a high temperature region. 3.2.3 Oxidability A H2-TPR method was used to determine the oxidability of these three samples and the resulting profiles can be seen in Fig. 9 . In the case of the CuO/TiO2 catalyst, at ca. 270 °C comes out a H2 reduction peak, demonstrating that CuO undergoes a reduction process to form metallic Cu according to the literature [21]. By contrast, an obvious increase in the temperature for the H2 reduction peaks could be observed for the sulfate-containing samples, which is indicative of the lower reactivity of surface oxygen species. That might make an inhibitory impact on the activation of NO x and NH3 in the lower temperature region and over-oxidation of NH3 at elevated temperature points to a certain degree, hence leading to a shift of the catalyst operating temperature window towards a high temperature region [22]. As is reported in the literature, H2-TPR profiles of these two sulfate-containing samples can be deconvoluted into four peaks. Peak A centered at ca. 290 °C could be related to the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+ in CuSO4. The reduction of SO4 2- in CuSO4 can explain the presence of peak B centered at ca. 355 °C. Peak C, located at ca. 360 °C, could be assigned to the reduction of Cu+ to metallic Cu; while the last peak (denoted as D) centered at ca. 415 °C can be attributed to the reduction of SO4 2- interacting with TiO2 [23–25]. Due to the interactions between CuSO4 and TiO2 during the catalyst preparation process and the loading amount of CuO below the monolayer coverage of TiO2, SO4 2- is not only bonded to Cu species, but also linked to TiO2 in CuSO4/TiO2 and CuO/TiO2+SO2 samples [26]. It should also be noted that no obvious changes can be observed in the temperatures for the reduction peaks of Cu2+, Cu+, and sulfate anions for the sulfate-containing catalysts, suggesting that these two samples exhibit similar oxidative ability [27]. An XPS method was adopted to measure the concentrations and valence states of the surface elements. As shown in Fig. 10 (a), two peaks of Ti 2p3/2 at 458.6-459.1 eV and Ti 2p1/2 at 459.8-460.3 eV could be assigned to Ti4+ species [28]. Compared with the CuO/TiO2 catalyst, Ti 2p bands belonging to the sulfate-containing samples shift towards a high binding energy region, which, to some extent, is consistent with the assumptions drawn from the H2-TPR results in Fig. 9 that, apart from Cu species, SO4 2- also interacts with the TiO2 support [29]. With respect to Cu atoms, the binding energies of these three Cu 2p bands are in good agreement with Cu2+ species (Fig. 10(b)) [6]. In the case of S atoms, sub-peaks of S 2p3/2 (168.5 eV) and S 2p1/2 (169.7 eV) are characteristic of S6+ in the form of SO4 2- [30]. In comparison with the CuSO4/TiO2 catalyst, the SO2-treated CuO/TiO2 sample presents a higher S content (Table 1), which is indicative of an increased number of strong acid sites and supports the conclusions drawn from the NH3-TPD data in Fig. 6 and in situ DRIFTS spectra in Fig. 7 to a certain extent. While for O atoms, it is well-accepted that peaks at 529.4-530.6 eV could be attributed to lattice oxygen (labeled as Oß); the existence of surface hydroxyl groups can explain the presence of the peaks between 530.6 eV and 531.7 eV (namely Oα), while the peaks with the binding energy higher than 531.7 eV can be related to chemically adsorbed oxygen (denoted as Oγ) [31]. Combined with the IR spectra in Figs. 7 and 8, it can be assumed that there are few hydroxyl groups on the CuO/TiO2 surface because of the negligible characteristic peaks indexed to this species. For this reason, the O 1s spectra of the CuO/TiO2 sample could be split into two sub-peaks; one is related to lattice oxygen and the other is attributable to chemically adsorbed oxygen [21]. While for the sulfate-containing samples, three peaks can be obtained through curve fitting (Fig. 10(d)). As is reported in the literature, chemically adsorbed oxygen is always considered to be highly active for the SCR reactions because of this species’ high mobility [5]. Therefore, the ratio of Oγ was calculated and then presented in Fig. 10(d). It can be seen that the Oγ ratio of the CuO/TiO2 (22.2%) catalyst is far higher than that of the CuSO4/TiO2 (9.3%) and SO2-treated CuO/TiO2 (8.8%) samples, indicating that catalyst oxidability is weakened by sulfate species [32]. Together with the H2-TPR profiles (Fig. 9), this phenomenon can explain the decreased low-temperature deNO x efficiency and enhanced high-temperature activity of CuSO4/TiO2 and SO2-treated CuO/TiO2 catalysts. 3.3 Discussions In Fig. 1, the apparent activity and selectivity of the samples were calculated. To obtain intrinsic information, we carried out a kinetic study and the data can be seen in Fig. 11 . The CuO/TiO2 catalyst possesses the lowest activation energy (18 kJ mol-1), followed by CuSO4/TiO2 (32 kJ mol-1) and CuO/TiO2+SO2 samples (46 kJ mol-1), which, to a certain degree, supports the conclusions from the apparent activity results. It is well accepted that NO x removal efficiency sometimes decreases to a certain extent at elevated temperature points because of the occurrence of some unwanted reactions involving NH3 over-oxidized to NO x [33]. Once NH3 is over-oxidized to NO x , SCR reactions can be somewhat inhibited because of the decreased amount of ammonia species participating in the reduction of NO x . This means that competition exists between NH3 reduction of NO x and NH3 oxidation to NO x under SCR conditions [14]. Based on the SCR data in Fig. 1 and NH3 oxidation results in Fig. 2, the NH3-related reactions on the series catalysts could be summarized as the following three parts: (1) reduction of NO x to N2 or N2O; (2) over-oxidation to NO x ; (3) oxidation to N2 or N2O through the internal selective catalytic reduction (iSCR) routes [3]. The iSCR routes can be further classified into two steps. The first step is that NH3 is directly oxidized to NO x , and the second is that the as-formed NO x is reduced by the adsorbed ammonia species with N2 or N2O formed. Therefore, the first step of the iSCR reactions and part (2) of the NH3-related reactions could be collectively called the catalytic oxidation routes (CO) [3]. Accordingly, the second step of the iSCR reactions and part (1) of the NH3-related reactions can be collectively referred to as the catalytic reduction routes (CR) [3]. As a result, CO and CR could be separated through calculating the selectivity of the NH3-related reactions. The corresponding calculation equations are listed below: (9) S N H 3 → N 2 = [ N 2 f o r m a t i o n ] N H 3 i n - [ N H 3 o u t ] (10) S N H 3 → N 2 O = [ N 2 O f o r m a t i o n ] N H 3 i n - [ N H 3 o u t ] (11) S C R = S N H 3 → N 2 + S N H 3 → N 2 O (12) S C O = 1 - S C R Fig. 12 illustrates the NH3 reaction selectivity results of the series Cu-based catalysts under typical SCR conditions, in which the detailed competitive relationship between CO and CR is discovered. In the case of the CuO/TiO2 sample, we can see that once the temperature exceeds 200 °C, CO begins to occur. Given that the reaction temperature increases, the ratio of CO shows an upward tendency, which reaches a peak value of 70% at 450 °C. By contrast, the onset temperature of the occurrence of CO increases from 200 °C to 350 °C and the ratio of CO also decreases in a certain extent for the sulfate-containing samples, suggesting that sulfate species sometimes promote NH3 reduction of NO x at higher temperatures. According to previous studies, it is acknowledged that catalyst’s physicochemical properties mainly decide the reaction proceedings [14]. After normalizing the reaction rate by the specific surface area, it can be concluded that chemical properties, namely acidity and oxidability, decisively affect the performance of the catalysts. On the basis of the SCR mechanisms, acidity is regarded to have a vital role in the catalyst deNO x behavior, because the adsorption of NH3 on acid sites is the beginning of this reaction. With respect to the CuO/TiO2 catalyst, the lack of acid sites restrains the adsorption of ammonia species in the high-temperature region, hence sometimes suppressing the NH3 reduction of NO x . Once the temperature increases, NH3 over-oxidized to NO x , the unwanted side reactions always determined by the oxidative ability of the catalysts, inevitably occurs. The presence of abundant reactive surface oxygen species on the CuO/TiO2 catalyst is favorable to oxidizing NH3 to NO x , hence making NH3 prone to being oxidized to NO x by O2 rather than acting as the reductant in the reaction of NO x with harmless H2O and N2 formed in high-temperature regions. The excess NO x elevates the NO x concentration of the simulated flue gas at the expense of the reductant NH3, thus causing decreasing NO x conversion and a negative deNO x efficiency above 350 °C. While at temperatures lower than 250 °C, plentiful reactive surface oxygen species of the CuO/TiO2 catalyst are advantageous to the activation of NH3 and transformation of NO to NO2, which can accelerate the reaction by a so-called “fast SCR” pathway [34]. That is why CuO/TiO2 exhibits a relatively high deNO x efficiency in low-temperature regions. Instead, some variations can be observed in the chemical properties of the sulfate-containing samples. Compared to the CuO/TiO2 sample, the existence of sulfate species weakens the oxidative ability of the catalysts, on which NH3 over-oxidized to NO x is suppressed to a certain extent. In addition, the presence of plentiful strong acid sites could still leave certain amount of the reductant NH3 available to reduce NO x to N2 even at elevated temperature points, thus leading to a promoted high-temperature activity. It is because of the generation of plentiful sites with strong acidity at the expense of the reactive surface oxygen species that the activation of NO x and NH3 is suppressed to some extent [35]. As a result, the low-temperature activity of the sulfate-containing samples exhibits a downward trend in comparison to the CuO/TiO2 catalyst. A similar routine could be used to explain the differences in the low-temperature performance of the CuSO4/TiO2 and CuO/TiO2+SO2 catalysts. Considering the similar oxidative ability of these two samples, the variations in the acid properties should be the main reason for this. According to the NH3-TPD results in Fig. 7, it can be assumed that compared to CuSO4/TiO2, an obvious increase in the surface acid sites can be observed for the CuO/TiO2+SO2 sample. The increased surface acid sites are primarily responsible for the far higher coverage of ammonia species on the catalyst surface. In this case, the NH3-SCR rate-limiting step, involving a redox catalyst function, would be adversely affected by NH3 adsorbed onto nearby acidic sites because of electronic interaction or possibly direct blocking of the redox sites [35–38]. This “NH3 inhibition effect”, which has been discovered in metal oxide- and zeolite-based catalysts by some research groups and only occurs at lower temperatures, could explain the relatively high activity of the CuSO4/TiO2 catalyst below 300 °C [35–38]. As the temperature increases, thanks to the similar oxidative ability, these two sulfate-containing samples exhibit a similar NH3 oxidation behavior, thus resulting in a similar high-temperature deNO x performance. Consistent with our previous study, the proceeding of the SCR main and side reactions is sometimes decided by the catalyst acidity and oxidability and the balance of these two properties has an important role to play in the performance of the samples [4]. 4 Conclusions CuO/TiO2, CuSO4/TiO2, and SO2-treated CuO/TiO2 catalysts were synthesized and their performance was tested. Some important conclusions are listed as follows: 1 For the CuO/TiO2 catalyst, around 75% deNO x efficiency could be obtained between 200 and 250 °C and the NO x conversion value becomes negative above 350 °C. The presence of abundant reactive surface oxygen species is favorable to activating NO x and NH3, thereby resulting in a relatively high activity in the lower temperature region. Due to this, the NH3 over-oxidized to NO x is also stimulated, hence causing a smaller amount of NH3 to reduce NO x with the rise of the temperature, and a decreasing tendency of high-temperature deNO x efficiency as a consequence. 2 For CuSO4/TiO2 and SO2-treated CuO/TiO2 samples, plentiful sites with strong acidity are generated at the expense of the reactive surface oxygen species, which causes an adverse impact on activating NO x and NH3 in the lower temperature region. This is also unfavorable to NH3 being over-oxidized to NO x at higher temperatures. Consequently, catalyst low-temperature activity decreases and the NH3 reduction of NO x makes up an increased portion in the reactions at elevated temperature points, hence resulting in promoted high-temperature deNO x performance. coredata.dc:description: In this study, a series of copper species supported on TiO2 catalysts were synthesized. With respect to the CuO/TiO2 catalyst, around 75% NO x was reduced between 200 and 250 °C and a negative deNO x efficiency was achieved above 350 °C. The existence of plentiful reactive surface oxygen species favored the activation of NO x and NH3, thus leading to satisfactory activity levels at lower temperatures. Due to this, NH3 over-oxidized to NO x was also facilitated and the portion of NH3 reducing NO x to N2 or N2O in the reactions showed a downward trend as temperature increased, which explained the decreasing high-temperature NO x removal efficiency of this sample. For CuSO4/TiO2 and SO2-treated CuO/TiO2 catalysts, the generation of plentiful strong acid sites at the expense of the reactive surface oxygen species suppressed the activation of NH3 and NO x to some extent at lower temperatures and also negatively affected the over-oxidation of NH3 to NO x at elevated temperatures, which explained the changes in the operating temperature window to a high temperature region.
coredata.dc:title: Insights into the effects of sulfate species on CuO/TiO2 catalysts for NH3-SCR reactions
